author: Western Morning News
title: Devon leads the way in demanding tough protection for Nature...
text:
By Western Morning News | Posted: April 28, 2017 By Keith Rossiter Comments (0) 
Devon's Tory-led county council has become the first in the country to urge the government to guarantee protection for wildlife after Brexit. 
Theresa May has not yet agreed to convert EU environmental regulations into British law, and the influential Tory MP Jacob Rees-Mogg has even suggested that they could be slashed. 
Mr Rees Mogg, the MP for North Somerset, said regulations that were "good enough for India" could be good enough for the UK â€“ arguing that Britain could roll back high EU standards. 
At their meeting this week, members of Devon County Council backed a motion by Claire Wright, Independent councillor for Ottery St Mary, asking for retention of at least the same level of protection for wildlife and environment, as provided by EU law. 
The State of Nature report published last October found that 15% of UK species are threatened with extinction, and half are in decline. 
Among the animals which are rapidly going to the wall are the kingfisher, water vole, willow tit and hedgehog. 
In Devon alone, 122 sites covering 115,000 hectares are protected by EU directives. 
"These are strong laws that are extremely helpful," Cllr Wright said. In her motion she said: "Leaving the EU puts at risk all of these protections and the government has not yet promised to retain the level of protections that exist under EU legislation." 
Peter Burgess, from Devon Wildlife Trust, said: "The council has made a momentous decision to be the first in the country to fully recognise the crucial role that EU directives have played. 
"Special protection is needed to ensure our best wildlife sites get even better: from the hundreds of thousands of birds which flock to the Exe Estuary; the most southerly breeding dunlin in the world on Dartmoor; to the Culm grasslands which are home to clouds of marsh fritillary butterflies, one of the top ten most threatened species in Europe. 
"Millions of people visit these landscapes each year and many livelihoods depend on their natural riches." 
Martin Harper, RSPB director of global conservation, said: "In Devon the nature directives protect special sites covering 38,614 hectares on land, and 48,257 hectares of the seas off the Devon Coast. 
"These include the blanket bogs, heaths and oak woodlands of Dartmoor, the cliffs along the Tintagel Coast; the rich mudflats, grazing marshes, sand flats and dunes of the Exe Estuary; and Dawlish Warren's otters, greater horseshoe bats and avocets."
